metadata.title: Development of duplex real time PCR for quick detection of Cryptosporidia in goats

abstract.text: Cryptosporidium spp. is the most important foodborne and waterborne pathogens and the leading 11 cause of mortality from foodborne and waterborne gastrointestinal disease. In neonates of 12 domestic animals it is associated with consistent diarrhoea and dehydration. Cryptosporidium 13 infection begins with the ingestion of sporulated oocytes disseminated by carrier animals that 14 consistently contaminate the environment. Many diagnostic tests are available including 15 microscopy, antigen trap ELISA, but none of the diagnostic tests available currently cannot 16 differentiate between active and passive infection in the host. In the current study, to address this 17 challenge an mRNA based duplex TaqMan ® probe PCR (dRT-qPCR) was developed to target 18 the Cryptosporidium oocyst wall protein (COWP) gene and 18ssu rRNA gene in a single tube 19 that can detect metabolically active Cryptosporidial oocysts. The mRNA transcripts are the direct 20

indicator of any actively replicating cell and it will help decipher the active stages of its lifecycle 21 in host. This diagnostic assay was standardized by computing transcript copy number-based limit 22 2 of detection. For COWP and 188ssu rRNA genes the limit of detection was 7.08x10 04 and 23 5.95x10 05 respectively. During active infections the oocyst wall protein will be active and so its 24 COWP gene transcripts will act as marker for active infection. While transcripts for 18SSU 25 rRNA are constitutively expressing in Cryptosporidial life cycle. This current diagnostic assay 26 will be a quantitative marker that will help assess active stages of Cryptosporidium infection in 27 neonates. The disease dynamics will help better understand to formulate the control strategies 28 and contain infection among the healthy animals. 29 Importance: 30 Cryptosporidiosis is an important neonatal disease affecting goats causing diarrhoea, dehydration 31 and stunted growth. For diagnosing this condition, many diagnostic tests are available including 32 microscopy, immunological tests, but none of the diagnostic tests available currently can 33 differentiate between active and passive infection in the host. The mRNA transcripts are the 34 direct indicator of any actively replicating cell and especially in intracellular parasites it will help 35 decipher the infective stages of a lifecycle in the host, and hence the test was developed in a 36 reverse transcriptional format in a duplex mode. The currently developed diagnostic assay for 37 cryptosporidiosis was evaluated for sensitivity using Limit of detection (LOD). This diagnostic 38 test will act as a quantitative marker to aid in detecting active stages of Cryptosporidium 39 infection in neonatal goats and will eventually lead to better control strategies for managing 40 cryptosporidial infections in the future.

body_text.text: of detection. For COWP and 188ssu rRNA genes the limit of detection was 7.08x10 04 and 23 5.95x10 05 respectively. During active infections the oocyst wall protein will be active and so its 24 COWP gene transcripts will act as marker for active infection. While transcripts for 18SSU 25 rRNA are constitutively expressing in Cryptosporidial life cycle. This current diagnostic assay 26 will be a quantitative marker that will help assess active stages of Cryptosporidium infection in 27 neonates. The disease dynamics will help better understand to formulate the control strategies 28 and contain infection among the healthy animals. 29 Importance: 30 Cryptosporidiosis is an important neonatal disease affecting goats causing diarrhoea, dehydration 31 and stunted growth. For diagnosing this condition, many diagnostic tests are available including 32 microscopy, immunological tests, but none of the diagnostic tests available currently can The already available diagnostic assays can only detect the presence or absence of 79 Cryptosporidium in a qualitative manner, and there is no scope to decipher the 80 metabolically/transcriptionally active oocysts from passive ones. Hence, a robust technique is 81 required that can able to differentiate the active oocysts from dead oocyst in passive infection. 82 In detail, the main aim of this study is to develop and standardize an mRNA based 83 Cryptosporidium spp.-specific real-time PCR assay using two important target genes viz. 18 84 small subunit ribosomal RNA (18SSU rRNA) and Cryptosporidium oocyst wall (COWP). The 85 18ssu rRNA gene is highly abundant in terms of genomic copies and it has high transcripts that 86 can increase the sensitivity of the assay, while the COWP is available only in transcriptionally 87 active live cryptosporidial oocysts. (13-23, 28-31). Hence, in the current study we report an mRNA based TaqMan® probe duplex real time PCR 89 that can able to detect the metabolically active Cryptosporidium oocysts from dead oocysts in 90 passively infected animals 91

FIGREF0.text: 33 differentiate between active and passive infection in the host. The mRNA transcripts are the 34 direct indicator of any actively replicating cell and especially in intracellular parasites it will help 35 decipher the infective stages of a lifecycle in the host, and hence the test was developed in a 36 reverse transcriptional format in a duplex mode. The currently developed diagnostic assay for 37 cryptosporidiosis was evaluated for sensitivity using Limit of detection (LOD). This diagnostic 38 test will act as a quantitative marker to aid in detecting active stages of Cryptosporidium 39 infection in neonatal goats and will eventually lead to better control strategies for managing 40 cryptosporidial infections in the future. 4 Diagnosis still plays a very important role because in neonatal animals many other diseases like 67 colibacillosis, rotaviral diarrhoea caused by group A rotavirus (GARV) and bovine corona virus 68 (BCoV) occurs commonly and there is a need to differentiate them or identify them collectively 69 in case of mixed infection. While coccidiosis occurs in weaned animals in later stages that might 70 perplex in the proper diagnosis. Microscopy is an excellent tool and can be highly specific but 71 requires expertise and experience in identification of the weak acid fast round oocysts from other 72 artefacts similar to them. Besides conventional microscopy and staining, molecular diagnostic 73 approaches like PCR are also gaining momentum Molecular diagnostic assays are usually 74 regarded as more sensitive compared to microscopy and serological diagnosis in human and 75 animals for the detection of Cryptosporidium in several studies (13-23). The molecular assays 76 are determined by the factors like stage of life cycle/infection as well as method of nucleic acid 77 extraction for targeting the Cryptosporidium spp. ( 24-27).

FIGREF8.text: cDNA (prepared from faecal RNA positive for Cryptosporidium both by microscopy and 130 conventional PCR). Based on the titrations, the primer or probe concentration that has produced 131 the best RFU value and the Cq values were taken as the optimal concentration. So as per the 132 results (Fig.4), for COWP gene the optimal primer and probe concentrations were 8picomoles 133 (for both forward and reverse primers) and 10picomoles respectively. Similarly, the optimal 134 primer and probe concentrations for 18ssurRNA are 4picomoles (each of the primers) and 4pmol 135 for probe. Henceforth these standardized concentrations were used for assay of unknown 136 samples suspected for Cryptosporidium throughout the study for the current diagnostic137 technique.138

FIGREF14.text: Duplex reverse transcription TaqMan ® Probe Real time PCR for COWP (FAM) and 187 18ssu rRNA gene of Cryptosporidium from positive cDNA with standard curve, 7b Extracted 188 image of COWP gene only from the duplex real time PCR data and 7c Extracted image of 18ssu 189 rRNA gene only from the duplex real time PCR data.190 Duplex reverse transcription TaqMan probe based Quantitative real time PCR (dRTsamples including unknown (clinically positive and cryptosporidia infected <1month olf 194 goat kids) and control (Carrier status apparently healthy <1month goat kid positive for 195 crytosporidial oocyst by microscopy) were assayed using Cryptosporidal dRT-qPCR along with 196 NTC and NRT controls. The results and the fold change are given in the table below 197 Table 5 Relative quantification of COWP and 18ssu rRNA by dRT-an important disease, which causes the diarrheal illness in neonatal animals 202 associated with other diarrheal pathogens or as alone (32). However, it is difficult to diagnose 203 cryptosporidiosis alone from other major etiologies of neonatal diarrhoea complex in neonatal 204 animals including E.coli, Group A Rotavirus (GARV) and Bovine corona virus (BCoV). For 205 diagnosing cryptosporidiosis in animals faecal oocyst identification by modified Ziehl-Neelsen 206 staining acid fast staining is a preferred method. Although this method is enough to identify the 207 acid fast oocysts based on colour, shape and size, but it cannot provide details of the active 208 infective stages (33, 34). PCR is another method which is highly sensitive, specific and accurate 209 (if standardized), but cannot fix the aforementioned problem of identification of active live 210 oocysts from the passive or dead ones. Hence in the current study we have developed a reverse 211 transcription based TaqMan probe duplex real time PCR for simultaneous detection of two target 212 genes viz., COWP and 18ssu rRNA that would provide better detail on the active and passive 213 stages of cryptosporidial infections in neonatal goats.

FIGREF15.text: Microscopy based detection by modified Ziehl-Neelsen technique was conducted as a 215 preliminary diagnostic screening for presence of cryptosporidial infection in suspected neonatal 216 kids. As observed, this technique could identify 39 cases positive for Cryptosporidiosis out of 61 217 sampled. Microscopy is only a primary test, but gives an overall idea about the presence of 218 cryptosporidiosis infection in the herd (21, 35-37). Therefore, many researchers used mZN 219 technique as gold standard method for the screening of large number of population because it is 220 much easier and non-invasive. Microscopy has certain limitations, like it may not differentiate 221 between the active and passive infections and its sensitivity and specificity is lower as compared 222 to ELISA and PCR (36, 38). 223 Specific diagnostic development with high accuracy and sensitivity is always on the priority to 224 diagnose the each disease. Rapid diagnosis is an important way to overcome the impact of 225 disease and appropriate treatment management. Diagnostic tests are inadequate, serological 226 diagnosis, novel faecal diagnostic analysis and biomarker are require to develop the more 227 accurate and sensitive identification of active Cryptosporidium infection (6).

FIGREF16.text: using conventional PCR, followed by DNA based TaqMan probe duplex PCR. Both the tests 230 identified the presence of Cryptosporidial DNA in the sample targeting the respective genes viz. 231 18ssu rRNA and COWP. 232 Similarly, the Primers and probes were also titrated in simplex and duplex modes at various 233 concentrations and optimised accordingly as given in the results. Eventually the optimal 234 concentrations of primers and probes were used in the dRT-qPCR assay for unknown samples 235 detection, standard curve using copy numbers and relative quantification based cryptosporidial 236 transcriptional response. As per the copy number based standard curve, the RFU is higher for 237 18ssu rRNA because of the abundancy of the transcripts, while for the COWP gene the RFU is 238 relatively lower and is present in clinically affected neonates with active cryptosporidial 239 infection. Hence, there is a scope to decipher the active live cryptosporidal oocysts from the dead 240 ones. Transcriptional activity is present only in live and metabolizing oocysts and their 241 subsequent infective or reproductive stages (gametogony) and hence this assay has the ability to 242 identify and at the same time quantify them based on gene targets used in the current study (34).243 The 18ssu rRNA is a constitutively expressing gene which is present in all stages of life cycle of 244 cryptosporidia, but transcripts for COWP gene is present only during specific stages and 245 especially the active ones. There is a dearth of information as far as reverse transcriptional qPCR 246 for cryptosporidiosis is concerned, because many researchers in the past used only DNA based 247 detection method (29, 39) and most of them were used rather as a diagnostic for differentiation 248 of C.parvum from C.hominis and other species (13, 30). Similarly sensitivity of detection is 249 another parameter that decides the efficiency of the diagnostic assay, and previously researchers 250 reported as low as 2 oocysts detected using TaqMan probe real time PCR assay and genus 251 specific tests have better sensitivity compared to species specific assays (40). Recently DNA 252 based commercial qPCR were tested for sensitivity and limit of detection, in which FTD stool 253 parasites kit detected 1 and 10 oocyst for C. parvum and C.hominis respectively (41), while the 254 in-house developed qPCR from the same research team showed up to 10 oocysts and 1000 255 oocysts for C. parvum and C.hominis respectively. Since most of these studies targeted the 256 genomic DNA, we cannot compare them directly with our dRT-qPCR which is reverse 257 transcriptional and targeting the RNA of the same pathogen. Also the mode of test was duplex in 258 the current study unlike the previous researchers in which simplex mode was followed for LOD 259 and sensitivity assays or multiplex assays involving other species like Giardia.260

FIGREF17.text: while 18ssurRNA was used as a reference gene because of its constitutive expressive nature in 264 cryptosporidial life cycle. Four clinically and microscopically cryptosporidia positive neonatal 265 kids were compared with the control kids which are apparently healthy with no overt clinical 266 signs but positive for cryptosporidia. This was done to actually assess the difference in 267 expression levels of COWP in these two groups (clinical and carrier) of cryptosporidial positive 268 animals. Also there is no logic in comparing the infected and non-infected animals, because here 269 the genes are from the pathogen itself and not actually from the host. 270 Previously, PCR based test has been established for the identification of Cryptosporidium 271 infection with higher sensitivity and specificity as compare to the conventional and other 272 methods which used to identify the cause the infection in gastroenteritis (42-44). PCR based 273 method gives the highly reliable and accurate results compare with faecal-smear microscopy 274 because of cross-contamination from the environment in the direct faecal examination (45). 275 Thus, PCR based test are helpful to identify the species or strain of any pathogens and 276 differentiate the responsible pathogens for causing the diarrheal illness by their epidemiology 277 and clinical manifestation (46). Therefore, this study used mRNA based TaqMan probe real time 278 PCR assay to reliable and new diagnostic tool for detection the Cryptosporidium spp. at different 279 stages of infection and differentiate the active and passive infection in host animal and humans.

FIGREF19.text: amplification system with low probability of cross-contamination as compared to other 282 conventional PCR methods(47, 48). This study showed the successful standardization and 283 development mRNA based TaqMan probe assay for targeting the 18ssu rRNA and cowp genes. samples were collected from Jamunapari and Barbari breed of goats from 287 ICAR-CIRG Mathura. Faecal sample were collected as lavage from neonatal kids in 1X sterile 288 PBS by flushing with the aid of sterile syringe (without any needle) through anal orifice (non-289 invasive method). The faecal lavage was transferred into a sterile 15ml falcon tube for further290   19    processing. The samples were centrifuged at 3500rpm for 30 minutes at room temperature. The291Middle semisolid hazy layer is used to prepare faecal smear for Modified Ziehlreagent (Cat# 9108) based protocol was used for RNA extraction of Cryptosporidium.296 For this 200µl of the processed faecal sample was reconstituted in 900µl of TRizol reagent in a 297 2ml of micro-centrifuge tube and vortexed at high speed for 30 seconds followed by incubation 298 at 10 minutes for room temperature. The mixture is further spiked with 200µl chilled chloroform 299 and briefly vortexed for 30 seconds followed by spin at 13000 rpm at 4°C for 15 minutes. The 300 clear supernatant was collected in new micro-centrifuge tube (without touching the interface) and 301 then equal volume chilled isopropanol is topped-up and allowed to precipitate for 30 minutes at 302 4°C. The sample mixture was centrifuged again at 13000 rpm for 15 minutes at 4°C. The 303 supernatant was discarded without disturbing the pellet and reconstituted with 1ml chilled 70% 304 ethanol to wash the pellet by centrifugation at 10000 rpm for 5 minutes at room temperature. 305 Repeated this step for again and carefully discarded the supernatant and the residual solvent was 306 aspirated with the aid of 10µl micropipette to obtain moist-free pellet. The Pellet is further air 307 dried for 3-5 minutes at room temperature and reconstituted in 30μl of diethyl pyrocarbonate 308 (DEPC) treated water. The freshly extracted RNA was quantified by mixing with Quantifluor 309 RNA dye (Cat# E3310) using Quantus Fluorometer® (Promega Technologies, Madison, USA) and incubated at 65°C for 5 min and snap chilled in ice. 2 nd Reaction Mixture was 316 prepared by adding 4.0µl 5x Primescript Buffer, 0.5µl RNAse inhibitor, 1.0µl PrimescriptRTase, 317 4.5µl RNAase free water in new micro-centrifuge tubes. The 1 st mixture the 2 nd mixture were 318 mixed in a new 0.2ml PCR tube incubated in thermal cycler for reverse transcription at following 319 conditions as per the thermal graph illustrated below.

FIGREF20.text: Cyclic conditions for cDNA synthesis in thermal cycler (Techne, TC 4000) 322 DNA Extraction from Cryptosporidium 323 DNA extraction 324 DNA extraction was also done for all the samples using the Wizard® Genomic DNA 325 Purification Kit according to the manufacturer's protocol (Cat#A1120, Promega USA).The 326 eluted DNA was quantified by Quantus TM Fluorometer® (Cat# E6150 Promega Technologies, 327 Madison, USA) as per the manufacturer's protocol and stored at -20 °C for further use.

FIGREF22.text: NCBI]; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/GenBank/). The primer sequences picked were further 333 analysed using Oligo Analyzer software for binding and thermodynamic properties. Primer and 334 probe sequences were then checked for cross-reactions with non-targeted sequences on the 335 GenBank database using the Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) 336 (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih .gov/blast/Blast.cgi) if any to rule out non-specific binding. Similarly337 probes were designed by the alignment of COWP gene and 18ssu rRNA gene sequences 338 according to the recommendations and general guidelines (Proudnikov et al., 2003). Reporter 339 dyes FAM (Fluorescein amidites) and HEX (Hexachloro-fluorescein) were conjugated at 5´end 340 of probe for COWP and 18ssu rRNA genes respectively while BHQ -1 (Black Hole Quencher) 341 used as quencher dye at 3´ end for both the probes. Primers and TaqMan® probes were 342 synthesised commercially (Integrated DNA Technologies, Inc.

FIGREF23.text: PCR was performed separately for the genes in a 25µl volume with 12.5µl 2x366    Emerald GT amp master mix (TaKaRa, Cat# RR310A) along with 10 picomole of each of the 367 forward and reverse primers for the respective genes, 1µl of DNA template and made up the total 368 volume with PCR grade water. All the components were mixed gently and amplification was 369 carried out in thermal cycler (Techne, TC 4000) as per the thermal graph below.370 Cyclic conditions for gradient PCR in thermal cycler (Techne, TC 4000) 372 24 Further the respective amplicons for the two genes were subjected to gel electrophoresis in 2.0 % 373 agarose TAE gel stained with Ethidium bromide along with 100bp DNA ladder. The DNA products were 375 visualized under the UV trans-illuminator and photographed using gel documentation system. 376 DNA duplex TaqMan ® probe real time PCR 377 After confirmation by conventional PCR, the primers and newly designed respective probes 378 (18ssu rRNA and COWP) were analysed for its proper binding using DNA-based duplex 379 TaqMan® probe real time PCR. The real time PCR master mix was assembled in duplicates for 380 each sample in a final reaction volume of 25µl in 8 strip PCR tubes with optically compatible 381 caps assayed in the real-time thermal cycler (CFX96 Real time PCR system ® , Bio-Radwith the 382 reagent preparation

FIGREF24.text: Standardization of Simplex Probe based reverse transcription real-time PCR:389Real Time PCR protocol was separately standardized for COWP and 18ssu rRNA probe and 390 primers using positive control cDNA. Probe qPCR master mix (TaKaRa, Japan) was used for the 391 quantitative analysis of COWP and 18ssu rRNA genes. Primers and probes were titrated serially 392 starting from 2pmol/reaction, 4pmol/reaction, 6pmol/reaction, 8pmol/reaction to 10pmol/reaction 393 for COWP and 18ssu rRNA genes individually(Table 8). All the reactions were performed in 394 duplicates in Premix Ex Taq Probe qPCR Master Mix (2X) (TaKaRa, Japan Cat#RR390) in a 395 final volume of 25µl per tube in a CFX96 Real time PCR system ® (Bio-Rad) with the thermal 396 conditions as described below. The reaction also included positive control (PC) and No template 397 Control (NTC) for interpretation of the results.

FIGREF26.text: for determining the relative expression (fold change) of target genes of cryptosporida in 465 total RNA isolated from fecal samples of neonatal goat kids used in the current study. In this 466 method, the ΔCq (cycle threshold) values for each cryptosporidia suspected goat kids were 467 figured out by subtracting 18ssurRNA Cq values from Cq values of gene of interest (in our study 468 it is COWP). The average ΔCq for samples from control group (healthy cryptosporidia oocyst 469 carriers with no clinical signs) are used as calibrator (ΔCq calibrator). ΔΔCq values were computed by subtracting the average ΔCq of calibrator 471 (healthy cryptosporidia oocyst carriers with no clinical signs) group from average ΔCq of 472 unknown animals (clinically and microscopically positive for cryptosporidia).

FIGREF27.text: Cq(target, unknown)−Cq(ref, unknown)]−[Cq(target, control)−Cq(ref, control)] 477 Based on the above formula the fold change or relative expression for COWP gene was 478 calculated by taking ΔΔCq as negative exponent of two, i.e., 2 -ΔΔCq . The fold change thus 479 derived represents the gene expression normalized to an endogenous reference or house-keeping 480 gene (18ssurRNA) and relative to the control. A fold change of 1 in control group was used as a 481 baseline for comparison with unknown animals (clinically and microscopically positive for 482 cryptosporidia).

TABREF7.text: Concentration and volume of reagents used in Probe based real-time PCRDuplex reverse transcription TaqMan ® Probe Real time PCR for Cryptosporidia afterAfter standardization and optimization Duplex reverse transcription TaqMan ® Probe Real time PCR for Cryptosporidia was performed with total reaction volume of 25µl with the same thermal cyclic conditions as above. Final reaction concentration of primer, probe and template for COWP 423 (FAM) and 188ssu rRNA (HEX) genes are given in table below.Table 11Final concentrations of primer, probe and templates in multiplex TaqMan ® probe basedLimit of detection assays for the Duplex Probe Real time PCR:To know the limit of detection (LOD) and other variables including regression coefficient, Yintercept, efficiency etc, of the current assay, a copy number based standard dilution was conducted by absolute quantification mode. Positive DNA amplicons generated by conventional reverse transcription PCR for COWP and 18ssu rRNA genes respectively were gel purified using Sigma GenElute gel extraction kit (Cat# NA1111) following manufacturer's protocol. The gel purified DNA were further subjected to quantification by mixing with QuantiFluor ONE dsDNA System, (Cat# E4871 Promega) and measured in Quantus TM Fluorometer® (Cat# E6150, Promega) as per the manufacturer's protocol. Copy number was derived based on the amplicon length (bp) and concentration of the purified amplicon by using the copy number formula available in the online tool (https://cels.uri.edu/gsc/cndna.html) as given below time PCR conditions and master mix assembled for the LOD were the same as mentioned in the previous section for duplex TaqMan probe real time PCR.Duplex reverse transcription TaqMan probe based Quantitative real time pcr (dRT-qPCR)Relative quantification was performed to quantify the transcriptional fold change of COWP (Target gene) vis-à-vis the 18ssurRNA gene (Reference gene). Since 18ssurRNA gene was constitutively expressed in cryptosporidia, it was regarded as a reference or housekeeping gene in the current study. For this relative quantification assay, 4 numbers of neonatal goat kids of less than one month of age were selected (based on screening from the 100 animals stock of same age group) for this study based on clinical signs (clinical status) like diarrhea, weakness and dehydration along with detection of positive oocysts in fecal mZN smear microscopy.Similarly, a neonatal goat kid of same age which is apparently healthy (no signs of diarrhea, dehydration, weakness, dullness etc.) but positive for cryptosporidial oocysts (carrier status) by fecal microscopy has been selected as control animal for the study based on continuous screening of healthy animals from a stock of 100 animals of same age group (<1month age). Further fecal samples from the kids with clinical status (Unknown) and carrier status (Control) were subjected
